awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites:  Jackson State University Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from Jackson State University Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship, establishes an I-Corps Site. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The Jackson State University Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship (JSU Center) strengthens their culture of entrepreneurship by supporting the translation of research from lab to market through training for faculty, students, and staff in the areas of academic entrepreneurship and innovation. The JSU Site:
-Offers entrepreneurial training and development opportunities for faculty and student teams in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines to prepare them for participation in the NSF I-Corps Teams Program or for further commercialization; 
-Broadens the participation of underrepresented, specifically African American, faculty and students in STEM and entrepreneurial training and development; and 
-Builds the capacity of faculty and students to explore the translation of academic research into tools, products, services, etc. that are favorable candidates for commercialization. 
These objectives are carried out through three major activities: 
-Twelve weeks of training for 30 STEM teams per year that emphasizes the role of customer discovery and the business model canvas in the journey toward commercialization.
-A year-long series of academic entrepreneurship workshops offered to the teams as well as to the campus community
-An end of the year Academic Entrepreneurship Networking and Engagement Session, hosted annually in conjunction with Mississippi Innovation Month and Global Entrepreneurship Week.

While progress has been made in understanding how to support scholars in the transition of research and innovations from lab to market, little attention has been directed to the ways in which faculty and students at minority serving institutions may require different levels of support or engagement to be successful in their entrepreneurial efforts. Teaching-loads, service requirements, and limited resources may hinder faculty of color at minority serving institutions from venturing into entrepreneurship. Lack of exposure to STEM professionals and limited access to information regarding entrepreneurship may limit African American students? opportunities to participate in research based academic entrepreneurship. Situating an I-Corps Site within the JSU institutional contributes to greater understanding of the best practices for overcoming the obstacles that hinder people of color and women in STEM from participating in innovation and commercialization activities.

Through teaching and learning activities for faculty and students in STEM, and by actively engaging faculty and students of color in academic entrepreneurship, start-up, and commercialization training and customer discovery, the JSU Entrepreneurship Center/I-Corps Site plays a major role in broadening the participation of underrepresented populations in STEM related entrepreneurial activities. The increased participation of faculty of color impacts society and the community in particular by bringing to market the products, process, services, and/or tools that are the result of research from a diverse pool of scholars and thinkers. The pairing of underrepresented students with STEM faculty and successful entrepreneurs also impacts the community by providing important networking, mentorship, and research opportunities - all of which are essential parts of recruiting and retaining students and promoting career advancement for faculty.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Jackson State University (JSU) I-Corps Site program significantly impacted the innovation and entrepreneurial ecosystem at Jackson State University. Funded by the National Science Foundation to train faculty and students to take their ideas from the lab to market, the program significantly impacted research translation, technology transfer, entrepreneurship, and innovation at Jackson State University. 

Through the efforts of the JSU I-Corps Site program, the JSU leadership supported the creation of the JSU Center for Innovation, Entrepreneurship, and Economic Development (CIEED) led by the I-Corps Site PI. Not only did the CIEED provide an interdisciplinary standalone location for the I-Corps Site to conduct its training, but support from corporate partners and the institution expanded the CIEED to include tools and resources to assist students and faculty in developing an entrepreneurial mindset, access to some tools and resources to assist with translating research and provide a space for peer mentoring, hacking of ideas, and business development.

The JSU I-Corps Site program trained over 400 faculty and students and had three teams complete regional programs. JSU has seen an increase in invention disclosures stemming from I-Corps Site participation. Additionally, three teams completed SBIR/STTR submissions and two received seed funds through the Mississippi SMART Accelerate program to further validate the commercial potential of their technologies. Three JSU I-Corps Site teams completed regional programs, with over five team academic leads submitting patent applications.

 

During the project period, the JSU I-Corps Site program trained fifty-nine (59) Teams as follows:

2017 ? 5 Teams - 1 Cohort

2018 ? 5 Teams ? 1 Cohort

2019 ? 15 Teams ? 2 Cohorts

2020 ? 14 Teams ? 2 Cohorts

2021 ? 15 Teams ? 2 Cohorts

2022 - 5 Teams - 1 Cohort

 

During the program, JSU sought to change the culture of innovation by building the capacity of faculty and students to explore the translation of academic research into tools, products, and services ready for commercialization. JSU also sought to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in STEM innovation and entrepreneurship. As a result, the JSU I-Corps Site program was leveraged to develop content to train faculty and students for other Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) on the Lean Launchpad Methodology, Customer Discovery Best Practices, Pains/Gains, and MVP. This expansion positively impacted more than eight (8) different HBCUs. In addition, a SBIR/STTR Readiness program for HBCUs and MSIs was developed with two external partners, as well as a partnership with the I-Corps Site at Howard University and Hampton University to lead the HBCU I-Corps Regionals program.

Building on the success of the JSU I-Corps Site program, JSU institutionalized the I-Corps Model as Venture Creation I in the entrepreneurship program. This course is required to graduate with an undergraduate degree in entrepreneurship. The JSU I-Corps program has positioned JSU to continue as a partner in the National Innovation Network (NIN), and to leverage its common interests with other research institutions to build capacity for research translation.

 

Intellectual Merit: Great strides have been made to support scholars in transitioning research and innovations from the lab to the market. Unfortunately, less attention has been directed to how faculty and students at minority-serving institutions may require different levels of support or engagement to be successful in their entrepreneurial efforts. Teaching loads, service requirements, and limited resources may hinder faculty of color at minority-serving institutions from venturing into entrepreneurship. Lack of exposure to STEM professionals and limited access to information regarding entrepreneurship may limit African American students' opportunities to participate in research-based academic entrepreneurship. Situating an I-Corps Site within the JSU institutional context will contribute to a much greater understanding of the best practices for overcoming the obstacles that hinder people of color and women in STEM from participating in innovation and commercialization activities.

 

Broader Impacts: Through teaching and learning activities for faculty and students in STEM at JSU, and by actively engaging faculty and students of color in academic entrepreneurship, start-up, and commercialization training and customer discovery, the JSU Entrepreneurship Center/I-Corps Site will play a major role in broadening the participation of underrepresented populations in STEM-related entrepreneurial activities. The increased participation of faculty of color has the potential to impact society and the community by bringing to market the products, processes, services, and/or tools that are the result of research from a diverse pool of scholars and thinkers. The pairing of underrepresented students with STEM faculty and successful entrepreneurs also has the potential to impact the community by providing important networking, mentorship, and research opportunities, all of which are essential parts of recruiting and retaining students and promoting career advancement for faculty.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/08/2023
Modified by: Almesha L Campbell
